comments.commentBody: I hope you realize that the gun report is far from complete. With 30,000 deaths by firearms in the U.S. every year that would come to about 82 deaths every day. The report would have to be about 20 times longer than what was presented if every gun death in the country were actually reported.

You have got to admit that some how guns are a part of the problem of gun violence. Our country has a much higher rate of gun violence versus other industrial countries. States with tougher gun regulations have less gun violence than other states.

Of course, they are the "tool" of the violence, and if the tool was eliminated, the gun related violence would go away. But that's not going to happen,

But doesn't it make any sense that if more and more guns are out there, this would result in more and more gun violence? So, shouldn't the opposite be the case, ie, if there are less guns, there would be less gun violence? Isn't that the rationale behind gun buyback programs?

You live in Maryland somewhere, I assume. How do you rate your state's gun regulations? Should they be relaxed or increased?

Martin,
Please don't put words in my mouth. I know that most gun owners are not criminals. I also understand that guns by themselves do not go off, that people with guns are the problem. That's pretty obvious, even for someone who does not have your background and experience with guns.

Still, a lot of people with guns cause a lot of injury and a lot of death, whether on purpose or by accident. There are a lot of guns in this country and a lot of people with guns in this country, and there is a lot of death and injury as a result.

This is a problem. It leads to criminals with guns robbing and shooting at other people, whether they have guns or not. It leads to accidental shootings. It leads to Aurora and Phoenix and Sandy Hook and the killing of John Lennon and the attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan, the wounding of James Brady, and a host of other killings.

Some of us, on both sides of the issue, want to find a solution to this. Take a look at the proposal put forth by Rob, above. That's a reasonable idea. Other people just want to keep the status quo. They twist other people's words, make false arguments and false equivalences, and try to distract from the discussion. Which side are you on? I'm still waiting to hear any attempt at a reasonable solution from either you, dwb, or BeadyEye.

Them or Us,
Yes I understand that some leadership of the NRA is very set in their ways, but if at the same time the NRA has had to become the way they are because of constant proposals on limiting the gun itself. It was the easy way out, to become against everything, I don't agree with that. However, the people that just want to take all guns away, is their easy way out. No one is addressing the issue of violence.You can't have gun violence without violence itself. I myself am an NRA lifetime member. I know it just got interesting. Somewhere along the way we lost the ability to have respect for each other.

Now I would disagree with you about the CCW for different weapons. All weapons need to be treated the same way, that never changes. Do some types penetrate barriers more than others, or are not as accurate as other. Yes, a 12ga shotshell will blow through wall and retain a good amount of kinetic energy, where a .223 Remington out of a 16" barrel AR-15 looses almost all of it's energy (why I recommend AR to shotgun for home defense with children on the other end of the home).

As far as law enforcement agencies not wanting to enforce. My friend that is why there are gun owners. The law is not going to jump out and stop a criminal from attacking my family , my community, or me. It will deter, but if someone makes the decision to break it, then it come down to the innocent citizen to determine how they will deal with it.

Clariette, I believe you.

dwb, I'm not nobody. This latest theme of yours (they're coming to take me, oops, my guns!, away!!) is one of your worst. Time to try out some new material, I think.

dwb, do you seriously think that manufacturers check to see who buys their guns? They might know what dealer they sent them to, but after that, not many people, manufacturers or otherwise, care where the guns go. That's why we need gun registration comparable to vehicle registration, and reliable record-keeping to keep track of everything, something the NRA is fighting tooth and nail.

Dwb, I was agreeing with you, my suspicion is that there is little-no correlation between rates of legal gun ownership in America, and murder rates. I was just trying to show that Them or Us's comment was disingenuous. I was thinking that since guns murders making up about 2/3s of homicides, then if we assume 50% of households have a gun, then that's about 2 times the rate of murder in gun owning homicides. It's just since most of those are committed with illegal handguns, and since the main tenets of the Brady act was that people  go out and buy guns to kill, that a waiting period reduce crime. It's a stretch to call those individuals gun-owners, in the sense of legal long term gun ownership. And I was saying that guns in the home are not much a a risk factor to speak of at all in terms of accidental death.

The old Steve Allen Tonight Show was the funniest program in the history of talk shows, with Louis Nye and Don Knotts and those unscripted 'man on the street' interviews. Steverino had the quickest sense of humor I've ever seen and I loved the way he would crack himself up and collapse on his desk top. I don't remember the lines but I remember how much I laughed.

I learned how to appreciate Carson's interviewing skills from my mother and I was first attracted to him because of his love of astronomy and because we both had the same kind of telescope, a Unitron.

NBC made a huge mistake not replacing him with Letterman, and the number of dumb moves made by NBC execs since then is remarkable.

But I also very much miss your show Mr. Cavett. Very witty and erudite and, in all those years of watching all those talk shows, the only time I was ever literally on the edge of my seat was when you interviewed John Lennon and Yoko Ono.

Yes Ricard, I was sentenced to spend time in NJ at McGuire AFB at that time, not too long after the Korean Police Action ended.

That is where I got my "love" for NJ. Fortunately, NYC was just a short train ride away. In those days the offices along Fifth Ave. and Avenue of the Americas were staffed mostly with women, and at quitting time the bars were 10:1 M-F. We would get tickets to the shows and just about any event at the USO, go to one of the bars and just mention that we had these tickets, it never failed to attract a good date.

Your right Wahoo Bob, it was Steverino, but that was 57 years ago, so my Alzheimers is kicking in.

Yes Norm, I watched Jerry Lester when I was still a senior in HS, he had Dagmar a tall blonde well developed lady on the show.

I'm older than Dirt ... and I remember, Back Home in Indiana, newly-graduated, living in India-NoPlace in 1955 ... those of us pining to move to NYC would gravitate to the one Naptown diner that resembled a Manhattan deli (think booths in aqua + orangle leatherette), order a Reuben sandwich, and wait for the owner (a Brooklynite) to tune in Steverino ... we'd watch the camera zero in on Times Square.
A year later, I'd made the move, and my roommate took me on the #1 train (the Noise! the crowds!) down to 43rd Street. We saw a looong line down the block in front of the Hudson Theatre. Roommate walked up to a mounted policeman and said, 'we're new in town and we're afraid we'll never get in to the Tonight Show." He said, "Follow me, little lady," and cantered over to the box office, said something to his pal behind the window and -- whoosh! we were in the 10th row, watching Steve Allen onstage, in overalls, learning how to mortar a brick wall.
Good times...

Gee Mr. Cavett, you must be younger than I thought. I began watching the Tonight Show with Steve Allen. So when Jack Parr came long, most of us did not think he was so great for awhile. Notice how many of Steve's show participants moved on to their own shows. You must remember Hi HO Stevo, or better yet, Hi Ho Nudo when Louis Nye talked about visiting a nudist camp.

Allen had the best guests of an of the show hosts. Now we have some actor telling us what a great job he did in some movie that most of us have never seen. You would laugh all the way through the show with Allen. In fact Carson was even a guest of his.

I never got tired of watching Steve, but I did get tired of Carson near the end. It seemed sort of stale by then. Then I saw Jay at a comedy club in Hermosa Beach, and he was good.

nobody believes you when you say that.

If that is your ultimate position, the basis for your sense of how to deal with the fact that America is on a par with Yemen when it comes to gun violence, you are the problem.

@Paul

I have no idea what would make you think I have much in common with @dwb, and I find it somewhat insulting to be compared to him.

This is a commenter who, despite efforts to cloak himself in the image of nice guy, suburban dad who wants to teach his kids the joys of hunting and also rescue inner city youth from poverty and gang violence, holds an extremist position re 2nd Amendment rights, clouds realities with streams of repetitive statistics, and is basically uninterested in any tangible or realistic solution to America's gun sickness.

Of late, this facade has cracked enough to reveal the latent bluster, anger, and conviction of being completely in the right that makes so many "law-abiding" gun owners seem like a frightening lot. Threats to "punish" those with differing views do not lead to confidence in the real agenda of "law-abiding" gun owners

It's the combination of knowing your cause is " right" and brandishing a gun that we should fear -- not government confiscation of firearms.

Solutions come from compromise, and compromise resides in the middle ground, not at the far ends of the spectrum.

I hope I am a person who understands how to get to "yes" in peaceful conflict resolution. That is not easy to achieve when there's a gun on the table. @dwb has a gun. I don't.

Drowning is a much bigger cause of death for children under 10 than guns. Per the CDC, in 2007, for children aged 1-9, there were 580 drownings and 38 accidental firearm deaths. Homicides accounted for another 95 firearms deaths and 12 drownings for this age group.

So a young child is safer in a home with a gun than a home with a pool.

John, I certainly understand your point about criminals getting guns by stealing them. However, a 1997 Justice Department study of over 18,000 state and federal convicts found that:

• 39.6% of criminals obtained a gun from a friend or family member
• 39.2% of criminals obtained a gun on the street or from an illegal source
• 0.7% of criminals purchased a gun at a gun show
• 1% of criminals purchased a gun at a flea market
• 3.8% of criminals purchased a gun from a pawn shop
• 8.3% of criminals actually bought their guns from retail outlets

I'm sure that the 39.2% from an illegal source certainly includes stealing them during a burglary.

Since the survey was taken of convicted criminals, I'd say the statistics are fairly accurate at best, and I'd take the results with a grain of salt.

I'm not sure that we can trust them to give honest responses to all of the questions . . .

Oh, given that criminals aren't likely to turn in their guns for the good of society, and the fact that the vast majority of guns turned in during the "gun buybacks" are broken, inoperable, and obsolete, your plan for gun buybacks, while laudable, is totally irrelevant. Gun buybacks have never been shown to influence gun crimes one way or another.

On a positive note, they give the little old widow down the street a place to turn in her husband's old hunting rifle where she's sure it won't get into criminal hands.

John, the little innocent children of Newtown should have had a school official (teacher, principal, counselor, whatever) who had access to a gun.

One locked safely in a biometric safe would be a good start. That would give the official time to retrieve the weapon and at least give them a fighting chance against the lunatic.

I know, what about the children in the crossfire? Well, it seems that there would have been far fewer children shot during a crossfire than there were actually shot, helpless and huddling in their classrooms.

I also think, during the last horrific seconds, that the brave school officials who charged the gunman sincerely wished they had more than their bodies to stop the gunman with.
